source.name: LA Sanitation and Environment (LASAN)
source.notes: Based on official LASAN recycling, composting, and waste disposal guidelines. LA uses a 3-bin system: blue (recycling), green (organics), black (trash).

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse the bottle
Replace the cap
Place in your blue bin
notes: LA accepts all plastics #1–7 in the blue bin
CRV bottles can also be redeemed at recycling centers for cash
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them
Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags

materials.name: Plastic containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove any film lids
Place in your blue bin
notes: LA accepts all rigid plastic containers #1–7
Lids can stay on or be placed loose in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't include styrofoam containers—those go in the black bin
Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags

materials.name: Plastic lids and caps
instructions: Leave caps on bottles when possible
Loose lids can go in the blue bin if larger than 3 inches
Very small caps may fall through sorting equipment—attach to a bottle
notes: LA accepts plastic lids and caps in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't throw loose small caps in without attaching to a container

materials.name: Milk and juice jugs
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace the cap
Place in your blue bin
notes: These are #2 HDPE plastic, highly recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't leave milk residue inside—a quick rinse is enough

materials.name: Plastic bags and film
instructions: Place in your black bin
Do NOT put plastic bags in the blue bin—they jam sorting machinery
Many grocery stores accept clean plastic bags for store drop-off recycling
notes: Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant in LA's recycling stream
Never use plastic bags to hold your recyclables
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic bags in the blue bin even if they have a recycling symbol
Don't bag your recyclables—place items loose in the blue bin

materials.name: Styrofoam (polystyrene foam)
instructions: Place in your black bin
Styrofoam is not accepted in LA's blue bin
notes: LA banned polystyrene foam food containers in 2023
Packing peanuts can sometimes be returned to shipping stores
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the blue bin—it contaminates recycling

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials (bubble wrap, foam, air pillows)
Place flat in or next to your blue bin
notes: Cardboard is one of the most valuable recyclable materials
Slightly wet or soiled cardboard can go in the green bin instead
commonMistakes: Don't leave boxes un-flattened—they take up too much space
Don't include pizza boxes soaked with grease—put those in the green bin

materials.name: Paperboard (cereal boxes, etc.)
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove any plastic liners or windows
Place in your blue bin
notes: Paperboard is thinner than corrugated cardboard but still recyclable in LA
commonMistakes: Don't include wax-coated boxes (like some frozen food boxes)—those go in the black bin

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Place directly in your blue bin
No need to remove inserts or glossy ads
notes: Newspaper is highly recyclable and valuable
commonMistakes: Don't bundle with rubber bands or string—place loose in the blue bin

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: Place in your blue bin
Glossy paper is accepted
notes: No need to remove staples or subscription cards
commonMistakes: Don't bag them—place directly in the blue bin

materials.name: Office and school paper
instructions: Place in your blue bin
Shredded paper should be placed in a paper bag before going in the blue bin
notes: Staples and paper clips are fine—no need to remove them
commonMistakes: Don't put shredded paper loose in the blue bin—it blows away and jams machinery

materials.name: Mail and envelopes
instructions: Place in your blue bin
Window envelopes are fine—the plastic window is removed during processing
notes: Padded envelopes with bubble wrap lining go in the black bin
commonMistakes: Don't put bubble-lined mailers in the blue bin—those go in the black bin

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in your blue bin
Can also be used to hold shredded paper for recycling
notes: Clean paper bags can also go in the green bin
commonMistakes: Don't recycle paper bags that are heavily soiled with food—those go in the green bin

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in your blue bin
No need to crush
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable and very valuable
CRV cans can be redeemed for cash at recycling centers
commonMistakes: Don't put cans with food residue in the blue bin—rinse first

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball clean foil together (golf ball size or larger)
Place in your blue bin
notes: Foil must be clean to be recycled—food-soiled foil goes in the black bin
commonMistakes: Don't recycle heavily soiled foil—it contaminates the recycling
Don't put foil-lined chip bags in the blue bin—they're not recyclable

materials.name: Tin and steel cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place in your blue bin
notes: Steel and tin cans are magnetically separated at the recycling facility
commonMistakes: Don't worry about removing labels—they burn off during processing
Watch for sharp edges when rinsing

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
instructions: Make sure the can is completely empty
Do NOT puncture the can
Place in your blue bin
notes: Only completely empty aerosol cans are accepted in LA's blue bin
Partially full aerosol cans are hazardous waste—take to a S.A.F.E. Center
commonMistakes: Don't put partially full aerosol cans in the blue bin—they are hazardous

materials.name: Metal bottle caps
instructions: Collect metal caps and place inside an empty steel can
Crimp the can shut so caps don't fall out during sorting
Place in your blue bin
notes: Loose metal caps are too small for sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't throw loose metal caps in the blue bin—they fall through the sorting screens

materials.name: Glass bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove caps and corks
Place in your blue bin
notes: All colors of glass (clear, green, brown) are accepted in LA
CRV glass bottles can be redeemed for cash at recycling centers
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass—wrap in newspaper and place in the black bin
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or Pyrex—different type of glass

materials.name: Glass jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove metal lids (recycle lids separately)
Place in your blue bin
notes: All colors of glass jars are accepted in LA's blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't include ceramic or Pyrex containers—they contaminate glass recycling

materials.name: Cartons (milk, juice, broth)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace the cap if there is one
Place in your blue bin
notes: Both refrigerated (gable-top) and shelf-stable (aseptic/Tetra Pak) cartons are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't flatten cartons—they're sorted using 3D shape recognition

materials.name: Food scraps
instructions: Place all food scraps in your green bin
Meat, bones, dairy, and cooked food are all accepted
Line your kitchen pail with newspaper or a paper bag to reduce mess
notes: LA's green bin accepts ALL food scraps under SB 1383 organics recycling
This includes meat, dairy, bones, and cooked food—unlike backyard composting
commonMistakes: Don't put food scraps in the black bin—they belong in the green bin
Don't use plastic bags to line your green bin—use paper only

materials.name: Coffee grounds and filters
instructions: Place coffee grounds and paper filters in your green bin
Tea bags can go in if they're paper (not nylon/plastic mesh)
notes: Coffee grounds are great for composting
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic or nylon mesh tea bags in the green bin—those go in the black bin

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
instructions: Place food-soiled paper in your green bin
This includes pizza boxes, paper plates, napkins, and paper towels
notes: Paper contaminated with food can't be recycled but is perfect for composting
Greasy pizza boxes should go in the green bin, not the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in the blue bin—food residue contaminates paper recycling

materials.name: Yard waste and trimmings
instructions: Place in your green bin
Cut branches to 4 feet or shorter
Tie large bundles and place next to the green bin on collection day
notes: LA collects green bins on the same schedule as trash
Large tree trimmings may require a bulky item pickup—call 311
commonMistakes: Don't put yard waste in plastic bags—place loose in the green bin
Don't include treated or painted wood

materials.name: Flowers and houseplants
instructions: Remove from pots and non-organic wrapping
Place plant material in your green bin
Soil can go in the green bin too
notes: Ceramic or plastic pots should be reused, donated, or placed in the black bin
commonMistakes: Don't put the pot in the green bin—only the plant material

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Greasy or food-stained pizza boxes go in the green bin
If the top half is clean, tear it off and recycle it in the blue bin
notes: Under LA's organics program, food-soiled cardboard goes in the green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in the blue bin—grease contaminates paper recycling

materials.name: Single-use batteries
instructions: Do NOT place in any curbside bin
Take to a S.A.F.E. Center (Solvents/Automotive/Flammables/Electronics)
Some retailers like Home Depot and Staples also accept batteries
notes: Batteries can cause fires at recycling facilities if placed in curbside bins
Tape the terminals of 9-volt batteries before transport for safety
commonMistakes: Never put batteries in the blue bin or black bin—fire hazard

materials.name: Rechargeable batteries
instructions: Do NOT place in any curbside bin
Take to a S.A.F.E. Center
Many electronics stores (Best Buy, Staples) also accept rechargeable batteries
notes: Lithium-ion batteries are a major fire risk in waste and recycling trucks
Tape exposed terminals before transport
commonMistakes: Never throw lithium batteries in the trash—they cause recycling facility fires

materials.name: Electronics (e-waste)
instructions: Do NOT place in any curbside bin
Take to a S.A.F.E. Center or certified e-waste collector
Best Buy accepts many electronics for free recycling
notes: California law prohibits e-waste in the trash
S.A.F.E. Centers accept all household electronics free of charge
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in the blue bin or black bin
Don't leave e-waste on the curb—it contains hazardous materials

materials.name: CFL and fluorescent bulbs
instructions: Do NOT place in any curbside bin
Take to a S.A.F.E. Center
Many Home Depot and Lowe's locations also accept CFLs
notes: CFL and fluorescent bulbs contain mercury and are hazardous waste
Place in a sealed bag for transport to prevent breakage
commonMistakes: Don't put fluorescent bulbs in the blue bin or black bin

materials.name: LED and incandescent bulbs
instructions: Wrap in newspaper or place in original packaging
Place in your black bin
notes: LED and incandescent bulbs are not hazardous but cannot be recycled curbside
They are different glass than bottles/jars and contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put light bulbs in the blue bin—they break and contaminate glass recycling

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Liquid paint: take to a S.A.F.E. Center
Dried latex paint (completely solid): can go in the black bin with lid off
To dry out latex paint: add kitty litter or sawdust and let it harden
notes: Oil-based paint is always hazardous waste
Many paint stores participate in PaintCare drop-off programs
commonMistakes: Never pour paint down the drain or in the gutter

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to a S.A.F.E. Center
Many auto parts stores (AutoZone, O'Reilly) accept used motor oil for free
Keep in a sealed, leak-proof container for transport
notes: Used motor oil is recyclable at proper facilities
Never mix different automotive fluids together
commonMistakes: Never pour oil down the drain, in the gutter, or on the ground
Never put liquid oil in any curbside bin

materials.name: Cleaning products and chemicals
instructions: Take to a S.A.F.E. Center
Keep in original labeled containers
Never mix chemicals together
notes: Completely empty plastic cleaning bottles (rinsed) can go in the blue bin
Only containers with residual product are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't pour chemicals down the drain
Don't put partially full chemical containers in the black bin

materials.name: Propane tanks and cylinders
instructions: Take to a S.A.F.E. Center
Do NOT place in any curbside bin—explosion risk
Blue Rhino and AmeriGas offer tank exchanges at many retail locations
notes: Propane tanks can explode in garbage trucks and at processing facilities
commonMistakes: Never put propane tanks in the trash or recycling—extreme fire hazard

materials.name: Medications and pharmaceuticals
instructions: Take to a medication take-back location (many pharmacies participate)
LAPD stations have permanent drug take-back boxes
Do NOT flush medications down the toilet
notes: LA County has permanent medication drop-off bins at many pharmacies and police stations
DEA National Prescription Drug Take-Back events happen twice a year
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications—they contaminate water supplies
Don't throw medications in the trash where children or animals could access them

materials.name: Sharps and needles
instructions: Place in a rigid, puncture-proof container with a tight lid
Take to a S.A.F.E. Center or participating pharmacy
Mail-back sharps containers are also available
notes: California law requires sharps to be disposed of in approved sharps containers
Never place loose needles in any curbside bin
commonMistakes: Never throw needles loose in the trash—they pose a danger to sanitation workers

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Place in your black bin if not reusable
Consider donating wearable clothing to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or local shelters
Some curbside textile recycling programs may be available—check LASAN for updates
notes: Textiles are NOT accepted in LA's blue bin—they tangle in sorting machinery
Donation is the best option for clothing in good condition
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing or textiles in the blue bin

materials.name: Bulky items and furniture
instructions: Schedule a free bulky item pickup: call 311 or use the MyLA311 app
LA residents get free bulky item collections
Place items curbside on your scheduled pickup day
notes: LASAN provides free bulky item pickup for LA residents
You can also use the MyLA311 app or website to schedule online
Consider donating usable furniture to organizations like Habitat for Humanity ReStore
commonMistakes: Don't leave bulky items on the curb without scheduling a pickup—it's illegal dumping
Don't try to fit furniture in your black bin

materials.name: Mattress and box spring
instructions: Schedule a free bulky item pickup: call 311 or use the MyLA311 app
California's Bye Bye Mattress program provides free mattress recycling
Some recycling centers accept mattresses directly
notes: California law requires mattress recycling (Bye Bye Mattress program)
Bulky item pickup is free for LA residents
commonMistakes: Don't leave a mattress on the curb without scheduling pickup

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Schedule a free bulky item pickup: call 311 or use the MyLA311 app
Appliances containing refrigerants (fridges, AC) require special handling
Some appliance retailers offer haul-away with new purchase
notes: Metal appliances have high scrap value and are always recycled
Free pickup through LASAN's bulky item program
commonMistakes: Don't remove refrigerant yourself—it requires certified technicians
Don't leave appliances on the curb without scheduling

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a S.A.F.E. Center or tire retailer
Most tire shops accept used tires (may charge a fee)
Do NOT place in any curbside bin
notes: Tires are banned from California landfills
Tire retailers are required to accept old tires when you buy new ones
commonMistakes: Don't put tires on the curb or in any bin

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Small amounts of cooking oil can go in your green bin (absorbed on paper)
Large quantities: take to a S.A.F.E. Center or used cooking oil recycler
Never pour oil down the drain
notes: Small amounts absorbed on paper towels can go in the green bin
Large quantities of used cooking oil can be recycled into biodiesel
commonMistakes: Never pour cooking oil down the sink—it causes sewer clogs
Don't pour liquid oil directly into the green bin

materials.name: Ceramics and pottery
instructions: Wrap broken pieces in newspaper
Place in your black bin
notes: Ceramics are NOT recyclable—they contaminate glass recycling
Consider donating unbroken ceramics
commonMistakes: Don't put ceramics in the blue bin—they look like glass but ruin glass recycling

materials.name: Mirrors and window glass
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Label 'BROKEN GLASS' for safety
Place in your black bin
notes: Window glass, mirrors, and auto glass have different melting points than bottle glass
They cannot be recycled with bottles and jars
commonMistakes: Don't put mirrors or window glass in the blue bin—different type of glass

materials.name: Drinking glasses and Pyrex
instructions: Wrap in newspaper or cloth
Place in your black bin
notes: Drinking glasses, Pyrex, and crystal are made with different additives than bottle glass
They cannot be recycled curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put drinking glasses or Pyrex in the blue bin

materials.name: Garden hoses
instructions: Cut into 4-foot lengths
Place in your black bin
Or schedule a bulky item pickup via 311 or MyLA311 app
notes: Hoses tangle in recycling machinery and are not accepted in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put hoses in the blue bin—they wrap around sorting equipment

materials.name: Diapers and hygiene products
instructions: Bag securely
Place in your black bin
notes: Diapers and hygiene products are not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put diapers in the blue or green bin

materials.name: Plastic utensils and straws
instructions: Place in your black bin
Consider switching to reusable utensils
notes: Plastic utensils and straws are too small and lightweight for recycling machinery
California has restricted single-use plastic utensils in restaurants (SB 1383)
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic utensils in the blue bin even if they have a recycling number

materials.name: Chip bags, candy wrappers, and snack pouches
instructions: Place in your black bin
These are multi-layer materials that cannot be separated for recycling
notes: Even though they look metallic, chip bags and candy wrappers are not aluminum
commonMistakes: Don't put chip bags or candy wrappers in the blue bin—they are not recyclable

materials.name: Receipts (thermal paper)
instructions: Place in your black bin
Thermal receipts contain BPA and should not be recycled or composted
notes: Thermal paper (glossy, shiny receipts) contains BPA/BPS chemicals
Non-thermal receipts (plain paper) can be recycled in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put thermal receipts in the blue bin—they contaminate paper recycling with BPA

materials.name: Construction and demolition debris
instructions: Not accepted in any curbside bin
Take to a licensed construction and demolition recycling facility
Small amounts from DIY projects: schedule a bulky item pickup via 311
notes: LA has several C&D recycling facilities
California requires 65% diversion of C&D waste from landfills
commonMistakes: Don't put construction materials in any curbside bin

materials.name: Scrap metal
instructions: Small metal items can go in the blue bin
Large metal items: schedule a bulky item pickup via 311 or MyLA311 app
Scrap metal yards will buy large quantities
notes: Metal is infinitely recyclable and has high scrap value
commonMistakes: Don't put large metal items in any curbside bin

materials.name: Pots and pans
instructions: Clean and place in or next to your blue bin
Metal pots and pans are recyclable as scrap metal
notes: Non-stick coating is fine—the metal is still recyclable
Very large items can be scheduled for bulky pickup via 311
commonMistakes: Don't throw metal cookware in the trash—it's recyclable

materials.name: Books
instructions: Place in your blue bin
Hardcover books: remove the cover if possible, recycle the pages
Consider donating books in good condition to the LA Public Library or Little Free Libraries
notes: Books in good condition are better donated than recycled
commonMistakes: Don't throw reusable books in the trash—donate or recycle

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place shredded paper in a paper bag
Staple or fold the bag shut
Place the bag in your blue bin
notes: Loose shredded paper blows away and jams sorting equipment
Alternatively, shredded paper can go in the green bin as a carbon source
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the blue bin—it must be contained in a paper bag

materials.name: Egg cartons
instructions: Paper/cardboard egg cartons: blue bin (or green bin if soiled)
Plastic egg cartons: blue bin (rinse first)
Styrofoam egg cartons: black bin
notes: Material type determines which bin—check what yours is made of
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam egg cartons in the blue bin

materials.name: Wax paper and waxed cardboard
instructions: Place in your black bin
Wax coating prevents paper recycling
notes: Wax-coated materials cannot be recycled because the wax contaminates the paper pulp
commonMistakes: Don't put wax paper in the blue bin—the wax coating makes it non-recyclable

materials.name: Frozen food boxes
instructions: Most frozen food boxes have a plastic coating and go in the black bin
Check for the how2recycle label—some brands are now recyclable
notes: The plastic/wax coating on most frozen food boxes prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't assume frozen food boxes are recyclable like regular cardboard

materials.name: Detergent and soap bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace pump or cap
Place in your blue bin
notes: Most detergent bottles are #2 HDPE, one of the most recyclable plastics
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with significant product remaining

materials.name: Empty non-hazardous aerosol cans
instructions: Ensure completely empty
Place in your blue bin
notes: Only completely empty aerosol cans go in the blue bin
Partially full cans of any product are hazardous—take to S.A.F.E. Center
commonMistakes: Don't put partially full aerosol cans in the blue bin

materials.name: Paper coffee cups
instructions: Place in your black bin
Plastic-lined paper cups are not recyclable in LA
notes: The plastic lining makes these cups non-recyclable in most programs
Plastic lids can be recycled separately in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put paper coffee cups in the blue bin—the plastic lining prevents recycling

materials.name: Wine corks
instructions: Natural corks can go in the green bin
Synthetic (plastic) corks go in the black bin
Some Whole Foods locations collect natural corks for recycling
notes: Natural cork is a compostable, renewable material
commonMistakes: Don't put synthetic plastic corks in the green bin

materials.name: Smoke detectors
instructions: Take to a S.A.F.E. Center
Some smoke detectors contain small amounts of radioactive material
Do not disassemble
notes: Ionization smoke detectors contain Americium-241 and are classified as radioactive waste
commonMistakes: Don't throw smoke detectors in the trash or recycling

materials.name: Fire extinguishers
instructions: Take to a S.A.F.E. Center
Do not put in any curbside bin—pressurized container
notes: Fire extinguishers are pressurized and can explode in waste trucks
commonMistakes: Don't put fire extinguishers in the trash or recycling

materials.name: Untreated wood and crates
instructions: Small pieces of clean, untreated wood can go in the green bin
Large pieces: schedule a bulky item pickup via 311 or MyLA311 app
notes: Only untreated, unpainted wood goes in the green bin
Treated, painted, or stained wood goes in the black bin
commonMistakes: Don't put treated/painted wood in the green bin—chemicals contaminate compost

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag securely and place in your black bin
Do not put pet waste in the green bin
notes: Pet waste can contain pathogens not eliminated in composting
Cat litter (even 'compostable' brands) goes in the black bin
commonMistakes: Don't put pet waste in the green bin—it's not accepted in LA's organics program

recycle: Plastic bottles, cups, lids, and containers (#1–7)
Aluminum cans, clean foil, tin/steel cans
Metal bottle caps (inside a steel can)
Milk, juice, broth, and soup cartons (including Tetra Pak)
Pots, pans, and small scrap metal
compost: All food scraps (including meat, dairy, bones, cooked food)
Food-soiled paper (pizza boxes, napkins, paper towels, paper plates)
trash: Chip bags, candy wrappers, snack pouches
Wax paper and frozen food boxes
Ceramics, mirrors, window glass, Pyrex, drinking glasses

recycle: Plastic bags and film—they jam sorting machinery

tips: LA uses a 3-bin system: blue (recycling), green (organics), black (trash)
Place recyclables LOOSE in the blue bin—never in plastic bags
Rinse containers lightly; they don't need to be spotless
Flatten all cardboard boxes to save space
All plastics #1–7 are accepted in LA—more inclusive than many cities
Food scraps (including meat, dairy, and bones) go in the green bin under SB 1383
Greasy pizza boxes go in the green bin, not the blue bin
Hazardous waste goes to S.A.F.E. Centers (Solvents/Automotive/Flammables/Electronics)
Schedule free bulky item pickup by calling 311 or using the MyLA311 app
CRV bottles and cans can be redeemed for cash at recycling centers
When in doubt, put it in the black bin—contamination hurts recycling
Batteries and electronics NEVER go in curbside bins—fire hazard

locations.name: S.A.F.E. Center — Gaffey Street
locations.address: 1400 N Gaffey St, San Pedro, CA 90731
locations.notes: Permanent S.A.F.E. Center for City of LA residents. Free drop-off for household hazardous waste.

locations.name: S.A.F.E. Center — Hyperion
locations.address: 7660 W Imperial Hwy, Playa Del Rey, CA 90293
locations.notes: Permanent S.A.F.E. Center for City of LA residents. Free drop-off for household hazardous waste.

locations.name: S.A.F.E. Center — Randall Street
locations.notes: Permanent S.A.F.E. Center for City of LA residents. Free drop-off for household hazardous waste.

locations.name: LASAN Bulky Item Pickup (311)
locations.notes: Free bulky item collection for LA residents. Schedule via phone (311) or the MyLA311 app/website.
